title of the franchise to resident evil and you  get what the game almost was hideki kamiya might  
be more popularly associated with high octane  action games like devil may cry in bayonetta  
but he was originally in the horror genre he  directed resident evil 2 and that game went on to  
be a massive success despite his lack of interest  in the horror genre with the success of that game  
he was later sought after to create another entry  in the resident evil series specifically for its  
fourth installment but this time around he would  be given complete creative control to do what he  
wanted the result was a more stylized action  game the main character tony redgrave was an  
invincible man with skills and intellect beyond  that of a normal person they tried really hard  
to make their main character and everything  around him cool but while it was a neat idea  
everything began straying too far from what people  came to expect from a resident evil title the  
original gameplay and horror elements were hardly  there anymore so instead the idea was shelved and  
reworked to be its own independent title and thus  devil may cry was born the game was developed by  
team little devils a group of staff members within  capcom who designed everything from the ground up  
the main character's name was changed to dante  and the world was no longer infested with zombies  
but demons since the franchise has gone on  to produce five games multiple light novels  
manga animated series and other supplemental  material the timeline for some has become   confusing due to the order and fluctuating canon  these stories have gone in and out of so i thought  
it was time i give you the complete unabridged  timeline of devil may cry let's rock baby
The Beginning
like most this story begins at creation darkness  was the first existing entity and from it spawned  
the demon world a hellish realm which was home  to nightmarish creatures demons are simply born  
in this world and as such it is where their  true strength is held here demons can unleash  
their full might and potential vying for power  it is in a demon's natural instinct to obtain  
power and influence no matter the cost as such  they are very selfish and cruel never showing  
remorse or pity to anyone or anything it needs to  step on to get there with such darkness plaguing

two worlds were originally one this wrought havoc  on the humans and in a not quite specified event a

was mundus also known as the prince of darkness  he is what many consider the epitome of evil  
he possesses a real god complex figuratively and  literally he dons the image of a muscular elderly  
bearded man very reminiscent to the likes of zeus  or other christian gods but if you wanted to take  
control of the demon world he needed power beyond  his wildest dreams power which was unrivalled  
fortunately for him he heard tell of the qliphoth  fruit it's a demonic tree grown in the underworld  
that when sufficiently nourished grows a fruit  that imbues that which ate it with divine power  
it's such a rarity that it can only grow once  every few thousand years to nourish it however  
it requires human blood the state in which it  grows is fairly unique as it is the inverse to  
that of a normal tree the roots are what break  their way to the surface spreading and sucking   the life out of any human it can find the qliphoth  is so powerful that it can even fuse the human and

------- Begin of Devil May Cry Timeline -------

In the beginning, there was only darkness. From this primordial void, the demon world was born, a hellish realm teeming with nightmarish creatures. Demons, born from this abyss, naturally sought power and dominance, driven by an inherent cruelty and selfishness. The emergence of such darkness inevitably led to the birth of light, giving rise to the human world.

Humans, though physically weaker than demons, possessed a vast array of emotions, feelings, and heart that demons lacked. The human world, born from the darkness of the demon world, was originally one with it, causing great turmoil for humans. A demonic god wielding a giant spear eventually separated the two worlds, bringing peace and prosperity to humanity.

Despite the separation, some humans worshiped demons and created portals known as Hell Gates, allowing travel between the two realms. The demon world, meanwhile, saw constant power struggles. Mundus, the Prince of Darkness, sought to dethrone the unnamed ruler of the demon world. Mundus, embodying the epitome of evil with a god complex, aimed to become the most powerful divine demon by consuming the Qliphoth fruit. This rare fruit, nourished by human blood, granted divine power and could fuse the human and demon worlds back into one.

Mundus's quest for the Qliphoth fruit led him to nourish the tree and consume its fruit, becoming immensely powerful. He overthrew the previous demon king and became the emperor of the demon world. However, his rule faced challenges, notably from Argosax, another powerful demon. Their struggle split the demon world into two, with each ruling half.

Mundus, undeterred, planned to conquer the human world by leading an army of demons. His right-hand man, Sparda, the greatest swordsman in the demon world, opposed this conquest. Unlike most demons, Sparda possessed qualities akin to humans, such as honor and wisdom. He rebelled against Mundus, protecting humanity with his righteous heart.

Sparda's rebellion was legendary, as he fought through hordes of demons to confront Mundus. Their arduous duel ended with Sparda sealing Mundus in a stone vault. Sparda's victory earned him the adoration of humanity, who revered him as a legend. He chose to remain in the human world, working tirelessly to prevent further demon invasions.

To ensure the safety of humanity, Sparda sealed the true gateway between the worlds, the Temen-ni-gru, using his demonic energy and the blood of a human priestess. He crafted a mystical amulet, known as the Perfect Amulet, as the key to this seal. Sparda also sealed a Hell Gate in Fortuna using the Yamato, another sword he forged.

Sparda's time in the human world was marked by his benevolent rule over Fortuna and his assistance to the protectors of V-de-Marley island, where he sealed Argosax using four relics. Over time, Sparda's story faded into legend. He married a woman named Eva, with whom he had twin sons, Dante and Vergil. These half-demon, half-human children inherited Sparda's demonic power and unique traits.

Sparda trained his sons and entrusted them with his swords—the Rebellion to Dante and the Yamato to Vergil. However, Sparda eventually disappeared, leaving Eva to raise the boys alone. Tragedy struck when Mundus's demons attacked their home, resulting in Eva's death. Dante and Vergil were separated, each believing the other dead.

Dante, following his mother's last words, changed his name to Tony Redgrave and dedicated his life to avenging her by hunting demons. He became a mercenary, taking unusual jobs that hinted at demonic activity. Partnering with the information broker Enzo Ferino and the gunsmith Nell Goldstein, Dante honed his skills and built his reputation.

Dante's path crossed with a mysterious mercenary named Gilver, who proved to be a formidable opponent. However, Gilver was revealed to be a demon under Mundus's command, created in Vergil's likeness. Gilver's actions led to the deaths of many, including Dante's partner Gru and his daughter Jessica, whom Dante was forced to kill out of mercy.

Nell, who had become a mother figure to Dante, was also targeted. Before her death, she gifted Dante specially crafted pistols, Ebony and Ivory, designed to withstand his trigger finger. Her death deeply affected Dante, leading him to abandon his alias and embrace his true name, Dante, fully dedicating himself to demon hunting.

The final confrontation between Dante and Gilver revealed the latter's true identity as a demonic experiment by Mundus. With Gilver's defeat, the demonic influence in the human world waned. Dante, feeling remorse for the losses, opened a bank account for Gru's remaining daughters and continued his journey as a demon hunter.

Dante, now around 18, moved to a new town with Enzo, who helped him secure an office space for his freelancing business. Their dynamic remained the same, with Enzo providing jobs and Dante taking those that intrigued him. As Dante's story continued, he faced new challenges, allies, and enemies, all while carrying the legacy of his father, Sparda.

In the latest chapter of the story, Vergil reenters the narrative. Having previously departed as a child in pursuit of power, Vergil's journey led him to the city of Fortuna, where his father Sparda once ruled. Vergil investigated the Order of the Sword, a militant religious organization dedicated to eradicating demons and worshiping Sparda. His discoveries revealed their desire for power, leaving him ambivalent about their motives but resolute in demonstrating his own strength as Sparda's son.

During his time in Fortuna, Vergil's unexpected personal detour resulted in a mysterious woman's pregnancy, further extending Sparda's bloodline. This subplot introduces a new layer to Vergil's character and the narrative, hinting at potential ramifications in the timeline.

Another significant development revolves around Arkham and his family. Arkham, married to Kalina Anne and father to Mary, is a scholar obsessed with the legend of Sparda. Arkham's pursuit of power led him to sacrifice his wife in a failed ritual, resulting in a severe burn and multiple alter egos, including the Jester. Arkham's demonic abilities, though not godlike, allow him to switch personas at will, complicating his identity.

Mary, disillusioned by her father's actions, renounces her name and becomes a devil hunter, driven by the desire to avenge her mother. Arkham's extensive knowledge of the Temen-ni-gru and Sparda's sealing of the demon world positions him as a pivotal figure in the unfolding events. His plan to claim Sparda's power involves breaking the seal, requiring the blood of a pure priestess (his daughter) and Sparda's blood, along with the perfect amulet split between Dante and Vergil.

Vergil, seeking a book in Arkham's library, encounters him and learns about the Temen-ni-gru's potential. Arkham's dedication and lack of fear towards demonic teachings intrigue Vergil, leading to an uneasy alliance. Arkham's true intentions remain hidden, as he seeks power for himself, manipulating Vergil's desire for strength.

The narrative also introduces several one-off characters, including the Mad Hatter, White Rabbit, and Alice, who appear to be demons allied with Arkham. The Mad Hatter is revealed to be another of Arkham's personas, adding to his complexity. Dante, hired by Arkham under the guise of rescuing Alice, faces numerous demons in a mansion, ultimately discovering that rescuing Alice was never the true objective.

Arkham's manipulations extend to Dante, whom he attempts to lure into renaming the seven sin demons. This leads to a reunion between Dante and Vergil, with their conflicting goals culminating in a fight. Vergil's desire to break the seal and harness demonic power stands in stark contrast to Dante's mission to eradicate demons. Despite their differences, they both play crucial roles in the unfolding events.

Mary, now known as Lady, seeks to kill her father and avenge her mother. Her journey intersects with Dante's, resulting in multiple encounters and a developing dynamic between them. Arkham, aware of her presence, attempts to manipulate her further, but Lady remains resolute in her quest for revenge.

As the story progresses, Vergil and Arkham continue their efforts to break the seal, while Dante and Lady pursue their own paths. The re-emergence of the Temen-ni-gru signals the beginning of Vergil's plan to release the demon world, drawing all characters towards a climactic confrontation.

Vergil, in his relentless pursuit of power, attempts to raise the Temen-ni-gru tower by restoring the perfect amulet and using his blood. To his confusion, these actions are insufficient, prompting him to question if more bloodshed is required. Dante arrives at the scene, and Vergil theorizes that adding Dante's blood might be the missing component. This hypothesis leads to another fierce clash between the brothers. As their blood spills in the chamber, Lady arrives seeking revenge on Vergil, bringing with her a confrontation where the truth about Arkham's deceptions is revealed.

Arkham, who had been masquerading as both Jester and his human form, reveals himself to still be alive. He finalizes the components needed to awaken the Temen-ni-gru completely. With the tower now fully awakened, Arkham opens a path to the demon world and claims Sparda's sword, activating it with the amulet. As Arkham grasps the blade, Sparda's demonic power flows through him, transforming him into the legendary Dark Knight. However, he quickly finds himself the target of Dante, Vergil, and Lady, each with their reasons for wanting him dead.

Lady takes it upon herself to confront Arkham, her father, seeking vengeance for his actions. Dante, however, argues that it is his responsibility to deal with the mess his father created. Despite Lady's initial resistance, she begins to understand Dante's motivations, seeing in him a demon fighting for humanity and a human as evil as a demon. She offers Dante her rocket launcher in exchange for his name, symbolizing her acceptance of his character.

Dante proceeds to the demon world, where he confronts Arkham. Despite Arkham's initial advantage, Vergil joins the battle, seeking to reclaim the power stolen from him. The brothers, using their childhood catchphrase "Jackpot," defeat Arkham, who is cast back to the human world. Landing in front of Lady, Arkham reveals his true desires for godhood and attempts to manipulate her one last time. Lady, however, refuses and kills him, finally avenging her mother.

Despite her victory, Lady is distraught, revealing a complex emotional history with her father, indicating that she once loved him. With Arkham dead, Sparda's sword is up for grabs. Vergil seeks its power, but Dante aims to keep it out of his hands. The brothers fight once more, with Dante emerging victorious this time. Severely wounded, Vergil leaves Sparda's sword behind, keeping only his half of their mother's amulet. As the portal between worlds closes, Vergil chooses to descend into the demon world, determined to follow in his father's footsteps, despite Dante's attempt to save him.

Dante, saddened by Vergil's decision and the events that transpired, returns to the human world. Lady, noticing his distress, remarks on his tears, leading to a poignant exchange where Dante admits that even devils may cry when they lose a loved one. With the conflict seemingly settled, Dante and Lady join forces, and Dante finally names his shop "Devil May Cry."

Vergil's fate is far darker. He encounters Mundus in the demon world and, blinded by his desire for power, rushes into battle. Weakened from his fight with Dante, Vergil is easily defeated. Mundus tortures him, mocking him for being a half-breed and vowing to strip him of his humanity. Over a decade of torment, Vergil is corrupted and transformed into Nelo Angelo, a puppet of Mundus.

During this period, Dante makes a significant business partner, J.D. Morrison, a broker who becomes integral to Dante's operations. Morrison, initially skeptical of demons, eventually believes in their existence after a perilous encounter involving a demonic firearm. This experience prompts him to contribute more actively to Dante's cause, opening a devil arms pawn shop.

As Dante's reputation grows, Mundus plots another invasion of the human world, this time targeting Mallet Island. To lure Dante, Mundus creates Trish, a demon in the likeness of Dante's mother. Trish's resemblance to his mother and her plea for help lead Dante to accept her request, guiding him to Mallet Island.

On the island, Dante faces Mundus's generals, including Nelo Angelo. Unaware that Nelo Angelo is Vergil, Dante battles him several times, eventually recognizing his brother during their final encounter. With both halves of the amulet and Sparda's sword, Dante restores the blade to its true form. Despite Mundus's attempts to defeat him, including using Trish as a hostage, Dante's resolve and newfound power allow him to triumph.

Trish, moved by Dante's actions, sacrifices herself to save him, reminding Dante of his mother's death. This act fuels his determination, leading to a climactic battle where Dante defeats Mundus. Trish, revived by the amulet and sword, assists Dante in sealing Mundus once more. The emotional reunion between Dante and Trish marks the end of their journey on Mallet Island.

Returning to the human world, Dante renames his shop "Devil Never Cry" in honor of Trish's transformation. The two continue to work as partners, developing a meaningful relationship based on mutual respect and understanding. Trish eventually leaves to pursue her own path, while Dante reverts the shop's name to "Devil May Cry," continuing his profession as a demon hunter.

The narrative delves into the events of the "Devil May Cry" animated series, an extension of the popular video game franchise. The series comprises 12 episodes that offer a closer look at Dante's daily life and the various demons he confronts to earn a living. The show introduces Morrison, Dante's broker, who gets more screen time, allowing viewers to see his role in Dante's life.

Most episodes focus on standalone stories that don't significantly impact the broader timeline. For instance, Dante stops a demon that kills through racing, competes in a life-or-death poker game, and connects two lovers in a Romeo and Juliet scenario where Romeo is a demon. These episodes expand on the concept of demons possessing human emotions, similar to Dante's father and Trish.

However, a few episodes are crucial to the series' overall narrative. In Episode 8, "Once Upon a Time," Dante is tracked down by his childhood friend Ernest, who brings him back to Morris Island. Ernest is determined to prove Dante's innocence in a past attack by summoning and killing the responsible demon with a shotgun. The plan fails, forcing Dante to fight the demon. Ernest discovers that the demon came to the town because of Dante and blames him for everything, ending their friendship. Dante leaves sorrowful, having lost an old friend.

New friendships form, particularly between Lady and Trish. In the episode "Rolling Thunder," the two meet for the first time and clash due to a misunderstanding orchestrated by a demon pretending to be a priest. After several intense encounters, Dante reveals the truth, leading to the demon's defeat. Lady and Trish develop mutual respect and camaraderie, often teaming up to tease Dante.

The overarching plot involves a nine-year-old orphan named Patty Lowell. In the first episode, Dante is hired to protect her, believing she is the heiress to a large fortune. By the episode's end, it's revealed that another woman used Patty as a decoy to travel safely. Despite the deception, Dante continues to protect Patty, who chooses to stay with him. Patty's character provides color commentary and has a more significant role than initially apparent. She is a descendant of a powerful alchemist, Alan Lowell, who created a pendant called Alan's Tear to seal away a powerful demon named Abigail. The pendant, passed down through generations, eventually reaches Patty, making her a target for demons.

The primary antagonist is a lesser demon named Sid, who manipulates events to break Abigail's seal and claim his power. Sid's plan involves orchestrating various events, including Dante's return to Morris Island and defeating Sparta's apprentices. As Sid nears his goal, he kidnaps Patty's mother, Nina Lowell, and demands Alan's Tear. Patty bravely confronts Sid and trades the pendant for her mother's safety. Sid uses the pendant to unleash Abigail's power, trapping Dante in a comatose state in the demon world. Patty's desperate pleas wake Dante, who defeats Sid and restores balance. Patty reunites with her mother, and Dante returns to his usual jobs with Morrison, with Trish and Lady as his close allies.

Dante's next adventure is detailed in the "Devil May Cry 2" light novel, introducing a new character named Beryl. Beryl's backstory involves her father's tragic attempt to harness a demonic item called the Beast Heads, leading to his transformation into a demon. Beryl becomes a devil hunter, seeking to destroy the Beast Heads. She hires Dante for help, and they face various challenges, including an underworld crime syndicate led by a man named Chen. The novel explores an alternate reality where Mundus captured Dante as a child, and Vergil, as Nelo Angelo, led a resistance against him. Dante and Beryl ultimately destroy the Beast Heads, and Beryl thanks Dante by giving him her weapon. Beryl's fate remains uncertain, with hints of her possible return in the timeline.

The events set the stage for "Devil May Cry 2," where Dante, now 33, faces the demon Argosax. An evil businessman named Aryus seeks to become an immortal sorcerer and targets the island of Veda Marley, guarded by a group called the Protectors. Lucia, a protector and artificial demon created by Aryus, invites Dante to help. The game's plot involves collecting four sacred relics to summon Argosax, Aryus's transformation and defeat, and Dante's journey to the demon world to vanquish Argosax. Despite the claim that Dante would be trapped, he returns through a random portal. Lucia accepts her nature, and the story ends with her and Dante reuniting. Dante resumes his devil-hunting duties, while Lucia continues protecting Veda Marley.

In the narrative of "Devil May Cry 4," the focus shifts from Dante to Nero, a new protagonist with a mysterious background. The setting is Fortuna, a city that worships Sparda as a god due to his historical significance in sealing away a crucial Hell Gate with the Yamato sword. This religious reverence led to the formation of the Order of the Sword, a group dedicated to eradicating demons, led by Sanctus, a devout follower of Sparda.

Sanctus, who once killed the former pope to rise to power, has grand ambitions of creating a demon-free paradise. He is aided by Agnus, a scientist whose contributions include anti-demon weapons, artificial demons, and the creation of the Savior—a powerful statue-like demon requiring Sparda's blood to control. Agnus also develops the Ascension Ceremony, a ritual to imbue members with demonic power, though it often results in madness for the unworthy.

Nero, the main character, is revealed to be the son of Vergil, Dante's brother, and was left at an orphanage in Fortuna. His childhood was difficult due to the stigma surrounding his birth, but he found solace in Kyrie and Credo, siblings who treated him like family. Despite his atheism, Nero joined the Order inspired by Credo's sense of justice.

Nero's life changes dramatically when his arm transforms into the Devil Bringer during a demon attack, revealing his latent demonic power. He trains in secret, unsure of how others would react. His relationship with Kyrie evolves romantically over time.

Meanwhile, Lady discovers demons collecting other demons and devil arms, leading her to learn about Fortuna's Order of the Sword. She informs Dante, who decides to investigate. Trish infiltrates the Order under the alias Gloria by handing over Sparda's sword, gaining a high-ranking position to gather intelligence.

Dante eventually arrives in Fortuna, learning about the Order's plans, including the Hell Gates and the Savior. During a sermon, Dante assassinates Sanctus, causing chaos. Nero fights Dante to protect Kyrie, revealing his Devil Bringer and catching Dante's interest due to its resemblance to Vergil's power.

Sanctus is resurrected through the Ascension Ceremony, and Credo is ordered to capture Nero, who becomes increasingly suspicious of the Order. Nero's journey leads him to Agnus's hidden lab, where he learns about the Order's true intentions and restores the Yamato, fully awakening his demonic heritage.

The narrative highlights Nero's struggle with his identity and the shifting dynamics within the Order of the Sword. The impending conflict between Nero, Dante, and the Order sets the stage for intense battles and revelations about their intertwined fates.

Credo receives orders to arrest Nero while Gloria volunteers to capture Dante. However, Trish, operating undercover as Gloria, decides it is time to reveal her true identity.

Sanctus, a pivotal figure, makes a crucial revelation about Nero's bloodline. He deduces that Nero, who possesses a demonic arm and has restored the Yamato, must be the child of a mysterious man he encountered 19 years ago, likely Vergil. This changes Sanctus' plans; they no longer need Dante to power the Savior if they can capture Nero. Agnes, overhearing Nero's cries for Kyrie, takes advantage of the situation.

Nero's confrontation with Credo is emotionally charged. Despite their lifelong friendship, Nero's distrust in the Order and Credo's unwavering faith in it lead to a battle fueled by emotion rather than logic. Nero emerges victorious, but Agnes, anticipating Credo's defeat, abducts Kyrie to lure Nero.

Credo, disillusioned by the Order's actions, seeks the truth while Nero falls into another trap set by Sanctus. Sanctus, needing confirmation of Nero's bloodline, duels with him and Agnes. After confirming Nero's lineage, Sanctus captures him and takes him to the Savior.

During his journey, Nero encounters Dante, who seeks the restored Yamato. Their encounter escalates into a fight, during which Dante realizes Nero is Vergil's son. After the battle, Dante, impressed by Nero's resolve, allows him to keep the Yamato. Trish returns, dropping her Gloria disguise.

Nero's confrontation with Sanctus ends unfavorably. Using Kyrie as leverage, Sanctus subdues Nero and extracts the Yamato from his arm. Credo attempts to stop Sanctus but is fatally wounded. Nero is absorbed into the Savior, leaving Dante and Trish to handle the aftermath. Credo, in his dying moments, reveals Sanctus' plan to release demons and exterminate them using the Savior.

Dante confronts Agnes, who now possesses the Yamato and uses it to open the True Hell Gate, unleashing chaos in Fortuna. Dante, characteristically unstoppable, destroys the artificial Hell Gates and confronts Agnes in a final showdown. He hints at humans having something demons lack before killing Agnes.

Dante ventures into the facility's depths to retrieve the Yamato and close the Hell Gate permanently. He returns to the surface and destroys the Hell Gate. To defeat the Savior, powered by Nero's demonic blood, Dante pierces it with the Yamato, freeing Nero. Nero confronts Sanctus, embodying Sparda's best qualities, and defeats him, rescuing Kyrie.

The Savior, now powered by Sanctus, becomes a slower, clumsier False Savior. Nero destroys it, ending the immediate threat. Fortuna is saved, and Dante bids farewell to his nephew Nero, who worries about Kyrie's reaction to his demonic nature. Kyrie accepts Nero as he is, reaffirming their relationship.

In the aftermath, Nero and Kyrie move into an apartment, with Kyrie helping those affected by the city's destruction through a soup kitchen. Nero, learning from Dante, opens a Devil May Cry branch in Fortuna, taking in three orphans: Julio, Kyle, and Carlo. Nero convinces the public to remain silent about the supernatural events, leading to a failed but passionate article by Jeffrey Turner.

The narrative shifts to Nicoletta Goldstein, Agnes' daughter, who seeks to further her engineering skills. Adopted by her uncle Rock Goldstein, she becomes infatuated with the craftsmanship of Dante's pistols. Despite her disdain for Agnes, she recognizes his genius and seeks his research.

Nico travels to Fortuna, guided by Jeffrey Turner's article, and meets Nero. Initially at odds, they eventually form a rocky friendship. Nico, staying with Nero and Kyrie, becomes his business partner, making weapons for his Devil May Cry branch.

Dante's subplot involves a return to Vie de Marlie to confront Balrog, a demon serving Argosax. Despite Lucia's training, Dante handles the situation alone, defeating Balrog and acquiring a new devil arm. Lucia realizes her romantic feelings for Dante, who remains oblivious.

One year later, Nero and Nico prepare to take their business mobile. Their lives are disrupted by the sudden reappearance of Vergil, who attacks Nero, seizing the Yamato and leaving Nero gravely injured. Kyrie and Nico witness the mysterious figure's departure, setting the stage for the next chapter in this unfolding saga.

In the aftermath of a brutal encounter, Nero lay bleeding profusely on the garage floor, with Kyrie and Nico watching helplessly as a mysterious hooded figure teleported away. An ambulance was called immediately, and Nero was rushed to the hospital, where he remained in a coma for several weeks.

Meanwhile, Vergil had returned to the human world after being tortured and controlled by Mundus for over twenty years. His escape from both Mundus and the demon world came at a great cost; his body was weak and deteriorating. Determined to gain the strength he desired to defeat his brother Dante, Vergil decided he needed to rid himself of his humanity. Using the Yamato, he plunged the sword through his chest, creating two separate entities: a purely demonic half, the embodiment of his lust for power, and a weak human half.

The demonic half, later known as Urizen, sought to consume the Qliphoth fruit to gain immense power. He opened a portal to the demon world, allowing the tree to grow into the human world. Urizen claimed the throne in the demon world and waited for the tree to mature, intending to nourish it with human blood.

The human half, adopting the name V, retained all of Vergil's memories and emotions but was physically weak. V formed a contract with Griffon, one of the four familiars expelled from Vergil's body, and sought to forge pacts with the remaining three: Shadow, Phantom, and Nightmare. V and Griffon encountered Shadow and Phantom, managing to defeat the latter with Shadow's help. Eventually, V confronted Nightmare, overcoming its illusions and forming a pact with it as well.

Realizing his limitations and the need for more allies, V decided to recruit Dante. He met with Morrison, who introduced him to Dante at Devil May Cry. V explained the situation, revealing that a powerful demon named Urizen was about to resurrect, and Dante agreed to take on the job, with Morrison enlisting Trish and Lady's help as well.

The group was flown to the Qliphoth tree, where they began their mission to defeat Urizen. During their journey, V felt the overwhelming power of Urizen and realized the gravity of the situation. While Dante, Trish, and Lady engaged in battle, V returned to Morrison and requested to be flown to Fortuna, where Nero was being monitored in a hospital. V successfully convinced Nero to join the fight, provoking him by questioning his confidence without his Devil Bringer arm.

Nero stealthily retrieved his weapons and set out with V to the Qliphoth. Meanwhile, Dante, Trish, and Lady continued their battle against Urizen, with Dante confirming Urizen's identity as Vergil. The battle raged on, with our characters' morale remaining relatively optimistic despite the dire circumstances.

Nero arrives to face the menacing demon king, Urizen. Despite his determination, Nero's single arm proves to be a significant hindrance, resulting in him being bloodied and battered, ultimately tossed aside by Urizen. Meanwhile, V ventures off on his own path, believing he can rejoin the fight later, assuming it will be over by then. However, upon arriving, he witnesses both Dante and Nero's failed attempts to defeat Urizen.

An exhausted Dante, determined to continue the fight, utilizes his Devil Trigger but quickly realizes the immense power Urizen wields. He urges Nero and V to escape, recognizing the futility of their current efforts. V heeds Dante's advice, pulling Nero away, considering him the only hope if Dante fails. V understands that Nero needs to become stronger, and with Dante preoccupied with Urizen, he sees it as Nero's responsibility to rise to the occasion.

As Dante battles Urizen, the demon king's power is so immense that he shatters Dante's sword, Rebellion, to pieces. Just when it seems Urizen will consume Dante and turn him into one of his puppets, Trish throws Sparta's blade to Dante, allowing him to harness its power. However, Urizen, believing he has surpassed the strength of the Sparta blade, blasts Dante and the blade out of the Qliphoth. Dante falls into a coma as a result.

With Dante incapacitated, Urizen captures both Lady and Trish, turning them into his minions. Lady becomes trapped inside Artemis, and Trish is transformed into Cavalier Angelo. Nero and V return to Morrison, informing him of their failure but noting that all hope is not lost. The Qliphoth still needs to grow, giving them about a month until it reaches full maturity. During this time, Nero must become stronger, as he is now their only hope.

Nero returns to Fortuna, realizing he needs both hands in action to face someone of Urizen's caliber. He requests Nico to make him a prosthetic arm, something she has already been planning since the incident with Vergil. However, she estimates it will take six months to create, time they do not have. The responsibility then shifts onto her shoulders to speed up production. A few days later, Nero learns about a Blitz demon in the forest and sets out to kill it, bringing Nico along to understand the nature of demon hunting.

Nico has a revelation that some demons possess organic and natural magical quirks. By studying and using demon parts, she can create the prosthetic arm more quickly. Nero scavenges the corpse of the Blitz demon, allowing Nico to understand how it harnesses electricity. She begins designing a new arm based on this knowledge.

Meanwhile, V's time within the month is introspective. He realizes the difference between Dante and Vergil lies in their views on humanity. Vergil always looked down on humans, while Dante saw them as equals and embraced his humanity. V decides to help as many people as he can in Red Grave City, even if it means saving just one person from the Qliphoth.

During his time in the city, V encounters a young boy whose unconscious mother is trapped under a fallen shelf. Initially dismissing the boy's pleas for help, V is reminded of his own past when he was left alone, asking for help. He saves the mother and son, reflecting on the importance of asking for help and realizing that fear and reliance on others are not weaknesses but strengths.

One month passes, and Nero and V return to Red Grave City to rendezvous. Nico successfully crafts Nero a prosthetic arm, dubbed Devil Breakers due to their design and tendency to break under stress. Nero and Nico leave for Red Grave City, where Nero sees this journey as a battle of pride to save Dante and the world.

Upon arriving, Nero makes a stylish entrance and faces a giant demon named Goliath. V watches from a distance, and when the battle nears its end, he finishes the demon off himself. V explains the nature of the Qliphoth to Nero and emphasizes the importance of reaching the bottom of the tree. They set off on separate paths to achieve the same goal.

Throughout their journey, both Nero and V encounter Urizen's generals. Nero unknowingly rescues Lady from Artemis, while V confronts Cavalier Angelo, sensing Trish trapped inside. V becomes determined to save her as a chance for redemption. However, his PTSD with Nelo Angelo triggers, causing him to collapse and allowing the demon to escape.

Nero and V rendezvous after taking down Gilgamesh. Lady reawakens and recounts her capture and Dante's fate. V pushes forward on their journey, and they are interrupted by more Angelos. V channels his trauma into anger, and alongside Nero, they defeat the Angelos. Following the fight, they land where V and Dante's childhood home once stood. V shares cryptic memories of his past before parting ways again.

V follows the aura of Sparta's sword, leading him to Dante's comatose body. Enraged that Dante always seems protected, V awakens him by plunging the sword near his head. Dante, now awake, understands the situation and heads off to fight Urizen, leaving V behind.

V reflects on his insecurities and desires for protection. Trish saves his life during a collapse, reinforcing his realization that he desires love and protection. Meanwhile, Dante ponders why his father gave him the Rebellion and how it was used to awaken his demonic powers. He theorizes that the Rebellion, in conjunction with the Sparda, can unlock a new power. He plunges the sword through his chest, unleashing a new Sin Devil Trigger.

Nero, after splitting up with V, confronts Urizen again but is defeated. Just as he is about to be killed, Dante returns, showcasing his newfound power. However, Urizen teleports away, leaving the battle unfinished. Everyone regroups, determined to see the journey through. Nico meets Dante, and they all descend the Qliphoth on separate paths.

V and Nero cross paths at Malthus. Nero encourages V to turn back, but V requests that Nero help him reach Urizen. Along the way, they unintentionally form a strong emotional and familial-like relationship. V reveals the truth about Vergil to Nero, and they reach Dante just in time to see him defeat Urizen. V approaches Urizen, dealing the final blow and restoring him to his true form, Vergil.

Vergil, now feeling strong enough to defeat Dante, challenges him to a final battle at the top of the Qliphoth. Dante reveals to Nero that Vergil is his father and sets off to face his brother alone. Vergil's familiars, Griffin, Shadow, and Nightmare, choose not to rejoin him, deciding they are better off without him. They intercept Dante, testing his readiness, and are defeated, putting an end to Vergil's nightmares.

The stage is set for the final confrontation between Dante and Vergil, with Nero grappling with the revelation of his lineage and his role in the ongoing conflict.

Dante and Vergil, having resolved Vergil's nightmares and trauma, engage in a fierce battle once again. During their clash, Dante reveals to Vergil that Nero is his son, a fact that Vergil, upon reflection, does not dispute as the timeline aligns with his memories from long ago. Meanwhile, Nero grapples with the revelation that Vergil is his father, a significant and overwhelming truth. Lady advises Nero against following in her footsteps of patricide, sharing her own traumatic experience of killing her father. Overwhelmed, Nero seeks solace and guidance from Kyrie, the one person he trusts implicitly.

Nero expresses his confusion and emotional turmoil to Kyrie, recounting how he felt alone as a child until he found companionship with her and Credo. Now, faced with the sudden revelation of having a family, Nero is unsure how to proceed. Kyrie reassures him, encouraging him to trust his instincts and decisions. Buoyed by her words, Nero resolves to confront his situation head-on, vowing not to fail in protecting his loved ones again as he did with Credo.

Determined and empowered by his newly unlocked devil trigger, Nero sets out to end the sibling rivalry with Vergil and ensure that neither he nor his father dies. Vergil sees Nero as a stand-in for Dante, believing that defeating Nero would be tantamount to besting Dante. The ensuing battle between father and son is intense, culminating in Nero's victory. Despite his defeat, Vergil is not overly troubled, as no one dies in the confrontation.

As the demon world begins to merge with the human world, it becomes clear that the roots linking the two realms must be severed to close the portal. Vergil, now empathetic towards humanity, volunteers to undertake this task, knowing it will trap him in the demon world. Dante, unwilling to let his brother face this danger alone, insists on accompanying him. Before descending into the demon world, Vergil entrusts his cherished poetry book to Nero, promising to challenge him again in the next encounter.

With Vergil and Dante heading into the demon world, Nero takes on the responsibility of protecting the human world. He contacts Kyrie, informing her of his imminent return. As the Qliphoth crumbles, the immediate threat is neutralized, suggesting a hopeful conclusion for the characters. However, the presence of lingering demons means that Nero must continue to safeguard humanity in Dante's absence.

In the demon world, Dante and Vergil fight side by side, battling any demon that dares to challenge them. This shared struggle brings them closer, showing a newfound camaraderie and understanding between the brothers. Time passes, and a month later, Dante has yet to return to the human world, leading Lady and Trish to fear he may be gone for good. In the meantime, they attempt to take over the operations of the Devil May Cry shop, although Morrison holds the deed to the building, making him the official owner. As such, Lady and Trish take on jobs to keep the business running in Dante's absence.

The narrative encapsulates themes of family, redemption, and newfound responsibilities, showcasing the characters' growth and evolving relationships amidst their battles against the demonic forces threatening their world.

------- End of Devil May Cry Timeline -------
